byline.contributor: Ben Sisario reported from New York and Noah Smith from Los Angeles.
byline.original: By BEN SISARIO and NOAH SMITH

abstract: Federal Jury finds Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams committed copyright infringement in hit 2013 single Blurred Lines, ordering them to pay $7.3 million to family of Marvin Gaye; found song had taken several elements from Gaye's 1977 song Got to Give It Up; decision amounts to one of largest awards in music copyright history.
lead_paragraph: The jury found that Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams, who share a songwriting credit on the song, had committed copyright infringement, and it awarded more than $7.3 million to Mr. Gaye’s family.

headline.main: ‘Blurred Lines’ Infringed on Marvin Gaye Copyright, Jury Rules
headline.print_headline: Hit Single Plagiarized 1977 Song, Jury Rules

snippet: The jury found that Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams, who share a songwriting credit on the song, had committed copyright infringement, and it awarded more than $7.3 million to Mr. Gaye’s family.
